message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the sense of vision in organisms. Elephants, like many other animals, use their eyes to see by sensing light. Option (A) is incorrect because trees do not have visual organs. Option (B) is incorrect because algae are single-celled organisms that do not possess visual organs either. Option (C) is incorrect because while worms have photoreceptor cells, they do not have eyes like elephants do.

This question requires basic knowledge about vision and the organs responsible for seeing. Eyes are the organs that enable organisms to see by sensing light. Option (A) is incorrect because trees do not have eyes. Option (B) is incorrect because algae do not have eyes. Option (C) is incorrect because worms do not have eyes. Option (D) is the correct answer because elephants have eyes and use them to see.

This question requires knowledge about the visual system and the organs that animals use to see. The eyes are the organs that sense light and allow organisms to see. Options (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect because trees, algae, and worms do not have eyes or visual systems. Elephants, on the other hand, have eyes and use them to see their surroundings.

Option (A) is incorrect because trees do not have eyes or visual organs. Option (B) is incorrect because algae are microscopic and do not have eyes. Option (A) is incorrect because trees do not have visual systems. Option (B) is also incorrect because algae are photosynthetic organisms and do not have eyes. Option (C) is incorrect because worms do not have well-developed visual systems.

Elephants, like humans and many other animals, use their eyes to see by sensing light. Trees, algae, and worms do not have eyes or the ability to sense light in the same way.

Options (A), (B), and (C) are incorrect because trees, algae, and worms do not have eyes and therefore cannot see or sense light.
